title: The Cause of Depression Is Probably Not What You Think | Quanta Magazine

last_post.content:
A very nice popscience article on what causes chronic depression.

https://www.quantamagazine.org/the-cause-of-depression-is-probably-not-what-you-think-20230126/

The predominant theory in neuro-psychiatric diseases/disorders is the "chemical-imbalance" hypothesis. For depression, the culprit is low levels of serotonin which has of course led to blockbuster sales of SSRI drugs. We are now, safe and sad to say, a drug addled society.

However, increasingly, studies are showing that serotonin levels alone can neither be the cause nor sufficient for occurrence for depression.

So, what if any are are the necessary and sufficient conditions to cause chronic depression?

The article goes through a few, none more prominent or critical than the other: different chemical imbalance (old tea in a new pot), genetic predisposition (only possibly accounting for 5% of the etiology), environmental factors like stress and other cues (especially to activate such a genetic predisposition), different and fewer neural connectivity than "normal", chronic inflammation that might lead to such fewer connections, and neuroplasticity changes/malfunction as the reason for inflammation and fewer connections.

Are all of the above factors causes? If so, are we classifying multiple different conditions into a single rubric called depression (which the article terms, "the umbrella theory" with a nod to oncology and cancer classification). Can we classify better? Are we missing other crucial factors?

Was depression, historically, as high as it is today? (I know we don't have much data, but let's overestimate how many were depressed centuries ago, was it as high as it is currently?). What about the ways we have structured our society and political-economy with rabid individualism and alienation at its core? Are they not potential causes of depression?

#neuroscience #depression #serotonin #psychiatry #genetics #neuroplasticity #mentalhealth

title: “Our special feature as humans is communication” – Podcast – EMBO

last_post.content:
Fun story about nature surprising the scientists. I learned this one from an excellent #EMBOPodcast with @CoriBargmann & @cyrilpedia.

https://www.embo.org/podcasts/our-special-feature-as-humans-is-communication/

The era was the human genome project (late 1990s). In question: how many genes do we have? Going in, they knew that a worm (with 302 neurons) had ~13K genes. The presumption was that we, with our billions of neurons (and other complexities), would have a lot more.

GeneSweep was the official betting pool, organized by Cold Spring Harbor. Of the 460 (presumably well informed scientists) who entered the competition, the winner was the one who made the SMALLEST guess (~25K). The mean guess was 62K; someone guessed as high as 200K.

The small number of genes in the human genome (25K) surprised nearly everyone.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GeneSweep

https://www.nytimes.com/2000/05/23/science/scientists-cast-bets-on-human-genes-a-winner-will-be-picked-in-2003.html

Fun story about nature surprising the scientists. I learned this one from an excellent #EMBOPodcast with @CoriBargmann & @cyrilpedia.

https://www.embo.org/podcasts/our-special-feature-as-humans-is-communication/

The era was the human genome project (late 1990s). In question: how many genes do we have? Going in, they knew that a worm (with 302 neurons) had ~13K genes. The presumption was that we, with our billions of neurons (and other complexities), would have a lot more.

GeneSweep was the official betting pool, organized by Cold Spring Harbor. Of the 460 (presumably well informed scientists) who entered the competition, the winner was the one who made the SMALLEST guess (~25K). The mean guess was 62K; someone guessed as high as 200K.

The small number of genes in the human genome (25K) surprised nearly everyone.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GeneSweep

https://www.nytimes.com/2000/05/23/science/scientists-cast-bets-on-human-genes-a-winner-will-be-picked-in-2003.html

We see a lot of concern today that renewables and other clean electricity will require too much materials, and producing those will break our remaining carbon budget.

For a correct implementation, see https://web.dev/website-navigation/ ✅

JavaScript, used sparingly, is *necessary* here. Don't try to hack it with html only, it's not worth it.

I am quite fed up with current state "AI" being hyped. It's so pathetic and has nothing to do with intelligence. That's just a clever marketing term, and it seems to be working :flan_sad:

Latest example is Google's MusicLM. It can create something like music from text prompts. Which is a cool feat, yes. But listen to the examples. They are so bad! Yes, you can hear what genre it's supposed do be. Yes, it's... Close to music. But it has nothing. No soul. No meaning. Not even words or melodies (!) that carry sense. It's tough to listen to more than a few seconds.

It's just probability, put to use.

It's "oh, after a sound that goes like this there's often a sound that goes like that in genre X." And frankly, for someone who loves to create and listen to music, these "songs" are close to torture in the way they defy everything I love about music.

You can find the "AI" here: https://google-research.github.io/seanet/musiclm/examples/

TIL `String.replace`'s `replacer` fn argument can operate on capture groups from the `match` arg if it's regex

```javascript
const fooBarBaz = 'foo.bar.baz'.replace(
/\.(.)/g,
(_match, p1) => p1.toUpperCase()
)
console.log(fooBarBaz) // => "fooBarBaz"
```

In 1952, Lawrence Chambers became just the second African-American in history to graduate from the U.S. Naval Academy. He went into naval aviation, and in January of 1975 he became the first African-American to command an aircraft carrier, USS Midway.

On April 29 of that year, after many years of slowly losing its war with its northern neighbor, the government of South Vietnam finally collapsed. That day and the next would see a mad dash by everyone who’d held a position of responsibility in South Vietnam to escape the country before Northern forces could seize them.

Among those fleeing was a major in the South Vietnamese air force, Buang Ky. Left behind by his government’s leaders, who were far more concerned about their own fate than the fates of those who had worked for them, Major Buang in desperation stole a two-seat Cessna, loaded his wife and five children into it, and took off for the sea, hoping to find an American aircraft carrier before its fuel ran out.

He did eventually find a carrier: the Midway. But by the time he did, the ship’s flight deck was crowded with helicopters that had carried higher-ranking officials out of Saigon. There was no room for Buang’s plane to land.

He dropped a note from his plane to the carrier deck, asking them to please move the helicopters so he could land. There were so many on the deck, however, that there was nowhere to move them.

The problem was so difficult that it made its way all the way up to Captain Chambers. Chambers gave the order: clear the deck. Helicopters costing more than $10 million in total were promptly pushed over the side to make room for Major Buang’s plane.

Despite having never landed on an aircraft carrier before — no South Vietnamese pilot ever had — Major Buang pulled off a perfect landing. He and his family would be repatriated to the United States.

Captain Chambers thought he would be court-martialed. Instead, he retired an admiral in 1984.

SOURCES/FURTHER READING

* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Chambers
* https://www.kpbs.org/news/2010/apr/29/midway-veterans-recall-fall-saigon/
* https://www.ocregister.com/2010/05/01/refugees-come-home-to-the-midway-after-35-years/
* https://lettersofnote.com/2011/03/21/permission-to-land/

title: Druid, a Rust-native UI toolkit, released v0.8 after two years of work by 80 contributors.

A huge milestone, Druid 0.8 was released today. This was a major effort, driven by Kaur Kuut and with many contributions by 80 people.

Kaur's notes at https://old.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/10n0t7l/druid_a_rustnative_ui_toolkit_released_v08_after/ tell the story about this release and the plans for the future. The biggest part of the story is that we have such a good community doing this work.

title: Neural correlates of individual odor preference in Drosophila

last_post.content:
The full connectome of the fruit fly is slowly being mapped out.
But how do we make sense of it? Sometimes the anatomy is highly suggestive of a function, but more often than not there are much more connections than we expect and the interpretation is complicated.

I've been slowly collecting papers that try to link a simulation of the connectome with a fly behavior.

Here, I'd like to share one such paper, which uses modeling and connectomics to study the link between development and fly preferences for a particular odor.

The paper is:
"Neural correlates of individual odor preference in Drosophila"
Churgin & Lavrentovich et al
(senior author @debivort )
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.12.24.474127v1

I presented the paper in the @tuthill journal club this week and wanted to share it here while it's still in my head! 🧵

#modeling #connectomics #Drosophila #neuroscience #PaperThread #JournalClub

@nyrath @gaditb @ComradeMusk @eldadoinquieto Thanks for the vote of confidence! This is probably the most important paper on the "Local Bubble": https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2003A%26A...411..447L/abstract

It is not actually clear though from the latest Gaia DR3 data if this structure is really a bubble or local. Instead it looks like the Sun lies inside a large region, possibly the interior of a spiral arm, that has a low hot star and dust density. It may be 200 or so parsecs wide but may be 1000 parsecs or more long.
